Comment: The CPB, Corporation for Public Broadcasting, was appropriated $535 million for FY 2025 from Congress. No more than 5% is allowed for CPB administrative expenses. About 70% is allocated to more than 1,400 locally owned radio and TV stations. Each station receives a combination of funding from federal funding, foundations, and support from viewers.   It was created by the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967 and signed into law by Lyndon B. Johnson. In 1968 it was registered as a nonprofit corporation in DC. It originally collaborated with the National Education Television (NET) but due to controversy generated by conservatives, it went into talks with private entities in 1969 to form PBS. NPR would be created in 1970, a network of public radio stations.   It has a 9-member board of directors, each to serve 6-year terms. Each member is appointed by the POTUS and confirmed by the Senate. A POTUS may not appoint more than 5 members from the same political party.   The lawsuit against the Trump administration (copied from [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corporation_for_Public_Broadcasting)):  On April 28, 2025, the CPB filed a lawsuit against the second Trump administration after President Donald Trump attempted to fire three of the five members of the CPB's board of directors. On May 1, Trump issued an executive order directing the CPB and all federal agencies to end funding for PBS and NPR.
